docs.snippet: One of the most intriguing comeback stories of the Olympics ended today when the German figure skating champion Tanja Szewczenko withdrew from the Winter Games after flu-like symptoms prevented her from practicing for nearly a week.    Until last ...
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most intriguing comeback stories of the Olympics ended today when the German figure skating champion Tanja Szewczenko withdrew from the Winter Games after flu-like symptoms prevented her from practicing for nearly a week. Until last fall, Szewczenko had been out of competition for 18 months after suffering from a life-threatening viral infection. But she recovered sufficiently to finish third at the recent European championships and was expected to challenge for a medal in the women's competition, which begins Wednesday.
docs.abstract: German figure skating champion Tanja Szewczenko withdraws from Winter Games after flu-like symptoms prevented her from practicing for nearly a week (M)

headline.main: Another Illness Interrupts an Athlete's Comeback

docs.snippet: EVENTS  Death Throes      LONDON -- A young woman is hounded by the press after the death of a child entrusted to her care. The plot sounds as if plucked from recent headlines. In fact, the events are taken from Pirandello's play ''Naked,'' first ...
docs.lead_paragraph: EVENTS Death Throes LONDON -- A young woman is hounded by the press after the death of a child entrusted to her care. The plot sounds as if plucked from recent headlines. In fact, the events are taken from Pirandello's play ''Naked,'' first produced in 1922 in Rome. On Wednesday night Nicholas Wright's new version of this exploration of the complexities of guilt opens at the Almeida Theater. Starring and making her English stage debut is Juliette Binoche, winner of the 1997 Oscar for best supporting actress for her portrayal of the nurse in ''The English Patient.'' The production, running until March 28, is directed by Jonathan Kent, the joint artistic director of the Almeida. Information: 44-171-359-4404.

docs.snippet: This is a tale of two terrific terriers, unrelated but similarly scrappy champions who epitomize the Norwich and Welsh strains and happen to belong to two families named Schwartz, families related only by their determination to bless this world, a...
docs.lead_paragraph: This is a tale of two terrific terriers, unrelated but similarly scrappy champions who epitomize the Norwich and Welsh strains and happen to belong to two families named Schwartz, families related only by their determination to bless this world, and themselves, with the perfect terrier specimen. With incessant care and campaigning, and with a fiscal commitment from their owners that soars into the six-figure stratosphere, Ch. Fairewood Frolic, the spunky Norwich, and Ch. Anasazi Billy the Kid, the effervescent Welsh, have become legends within their breeds but archrivals on the show-dog circuit. Their paths will cross, for the final and most important time, today at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.
docs.abstract: Article on Ch Fairewood Frolich, a Norwich terrier, and Ch Anasazi Billy the Kid, a Welsh terrier, who have become rivals in show-dog circuit and will compete at Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden; photo (L)

headline.main: Two Successful Terriers Are Dogdom's King and Queen

docs.snippet: COME back when you have something to show us.''  Frazer Pennebaker repeated the words most often heard when he was raising money for ''Moon Over Broadway,'' the latest of the documentary films his family has been making since before he was born. C...
docs.lead_paragraph: COME back when you have something to show us.'' Frazer Pennebaker repeated the words most often heard when he was raising money for ''Moon Over Broadway,'' the latest of the documentary films his family has been making since before he was born. Considering that their last film was the Oscar-nominated ''The War Room,'' about Bill Clinton's 1992 election campaign, you would think that financing would be guaranteed. ''Every film, we have to reinvent the wheel to convince people,'' said the energetic younger version of D. A. Pennebaker, a name that for some is synonymous with the very word documentary.
docs.abstract: Article on independent film makers D A Pennebaker, his wife, Chris Hegedus, and Pennebaker's son, Frazer, focuses on their documentary film, Moon Over Broadway, birth-to-death chronicle of play Moon Over Buffalo, a comedy with Carol Burnett and Philip Bosco that opened on Broadway in Oct 1995 and closed 9 months later; photos (L)

headline.main: Independent Film Maker Keeps the Process All in the Family

docs.snippet: The playwright, drowning in opening-night anxiety. The star, fretting over a high-visibility return to the stage. The ingenue, griping to the publicity man about the quality of her glossies. The producer, wondering if he should bring in a new joke...
docs.lead_paragraph: The playwright, drowning in opening-night anxiety. The star, fretting over a high-visibility return to the stage. The ingenue, griping to the publicity man about the quality of her glossies. The producer, wondering if he should bring in a new joke writer to maximize the laughs in his troubled comedy. Lame stereotypes from a bygone theatrical era, right? Guess again.
docs.abstract: Article on D A Pennebaker-Chris Hegedus documentary film Moon Over Broadway, a birth-to-death chronicle of play Moon Over Buffalo, a comedy with Carol Burnett and Philip Bosco that opened on Broadway on Oct 1, 1995 to lukewarm reviews and closed 9 months and 301 performances later; photo (L)

headline.main: The Staging of a Comedy, Or, Crying on the Inside

docs.snippet: Jennifer Anne Scully, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James H. Scully Jr. of Columbia, S.C., is to be married today to Richard Scott Lerner, a son of Linda Lerner of Swampscott, Mass., and the late Joseph I. Lerner. Judge Arthur J. Gajarsa of the Unite...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Anne Scully, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James H. Scully Jr. of Columbia, S.C., is to be married today to Richard Scott Lerner, a son of Linda Lerner of Swampscott, Mass., and the late Joseph I. Lerner. Judge Arthur J. Gajarsa of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit will officiate at the Cosmos Club in Washington. The bride, 28, is the director of investor relations at Oscar Capital Management in New York. She graduated from Vanderbilt University. Her father is the chairman of neuropsychiatry at the University of South Carolina and the director of the William S. Hall Institute, a hospital, both in Columbia.

docs.snippet: Joining a man and a woman before God is standard duty for members of the clergy. But for performing a union of a different sort, the Rev. Jimmy Creech, a United Methodist minister here, will soon be tried in a church court.    At issue is Mr. Cree...
docs.lead_paragraph: Joining a man and a woman before God is standard duty for members of the clergy. But for performing a union of a different sort, the Rev. Jimmy Creech, a United Methodist minister here, will soon be tried in a church court. At issue is Mr. Creech's officiation at a covenant ceremony last September uniting two women in his congregation, First United Methodist Church. The event resembled a Methodist wedding, with Scripture readings, an exchange of vows and a celebration of communion.
docs.abstract: Rev Jimmy Creech, faces trial in church court for officiating at covenant ceremony uniting two women at his Omaha, Neb, United Methodist church; Creech acted in defiance of his bishop and of recent denomination rule forbidding such rites; defends move, interview; trial will highlight divisive pattern emerging within Protestantism, where consensus against homosexuality has been eroding; photo (M)

headline.main: Pastor's Church Trial Attests To Divisiveness of Gay Issue

docs.snippet: * Hillary Clinton calls her husband the victim of a ''vast right-wing conspiracy,'' but it may be bigger than that. * New World Order conspiracy theorists, writing on the Internet, have suggested that mysterious bankers are using Monicagate to cro...
docs.lead_paragraph: * Hillary Clinton calls her husband the victim of a ''vast right-wing conspiracy,'' but it may be bigger than that. * New World Order conspiracy theorists, writing on the Internet, have suggested that mysterious bankers are using Monicagate to crowbar Clinton from office and usher in a more malleable Al Gore Presidency. * One anti-Semite has noted ominously that ''all the leading players in Clinton's sex scandal are Jews except Clinton,'' suggesting that he's being blackmailed to bomb Iraq. * Yet another wonders if Clinton conspired with the producer of ''Wag the Dog'' to make that film -- in which a President starts a phony war to distract attention from domestic problems -- appear prescient. * But why? The theorist believes ''this collapse between fiction and reality'' may have been part of ''a ploy . . . to get the Best Picture Oscar.''
docs.abstract: Sex scandal involving Pres Clinton has spurred number of conspiracy theories (S)

docs.snippet: Stephen Rea is famous for looking melancholic on screen, and on this occasion at least, he seemed little more cheerful in person. But he also had good reason for feeling gloomy. He had just flown into London from Dublin and was distraught over the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Stephen Rea is famous for looking melancholic on screen, and on this occasion at least, he seemed little more cheerful in person. But he also had good reason for feeling gloomy. He had just flown into London from Dublin and was distraught over the spate of sectarian murders that had bloodied the new year and now threatened the peace process in his native Northern Ireland. ''It's truly ghastly,'' he said, speaking almost in a whisper. ''I foolishly had hoped for some sort of improvement, but it doesn't seem to be coming. Everyone has become so used to the state of war that it becomes impossible for them to imagine anything else.''
docs.abstract: Article on actor Stephen Rea, who portrays a man who escapes from Belfast prison and makes his way to New York in film The Break; Rea comments; photo (L)

headline.main: Cast in the Middle Of the Long Conflict In Northern Ireland

docs.snippet: The compulsory dances had barely ended tonight at the Olympics when the controversy became as steamy as the Argentine tango.    The Canadian champions found themselves tied for fourth place after the waltz and tango, and saw a judging conspiracy i...
docs.lead_paragraph: The compulsory dances had barely ended tonight at the Olympics when the controversy became as steamy as the Argentine tango. The Canadian champions found themselves tied for fourth place after the waltz and tango, and saw a judging conspiracy in the outcome. The Canadian coach said that the Russian and French judges had colluded to rig the voting in favor of their skaters. It was yet another charge of intrigue in an event that has lost its credibility as a sport.
docs.abstract: Canadian ice dance champions Shae-Lynn Bourne and Victor Kraatz charge judging conspiracy following compulsory dance event in which they tied for fourth place (S)
